I normally prefer to review the disc release and not the movie but, obviously, this disc is not yet available and the movie is enough of an unknown quantity (evidenced by this being the first review) that it seemed an exception was due this time.

I came across FORTRESS by accident.  I had not seen any publicity for it and I follow movie releases fairly closely. It is apparently a low budget, independent production.  It is pretty ambitious for such a film.  To recreate the large bomber formations, fighter plane attacks and even the base camp it uses a lot of CGI.

So, I have seen FORTRESS and I very much enjoyed it.  Sure, the visual effects are sometimes a bit crude, but most of the time they are pretty effective and certainly good enough to support the story.  I'd say the visual effects are a bit better than those in the TV series DOGFIGHTS (which were pretty good) but not up to the standards of RED TAILS (a high bar, IMO).  The movie was well written and I was impressed by the performances by the unknown (to me) cast.  For a movie made on a tiny fraction of most big studio movie budgets it is quite an accomplishment.

Synopses of the story can be found on IMDb and if you haven't watched the trailer on YouTube, yet, do so.  If you like WW II movies, especially about the air war in Europe, I think you will like FORTRESS.

I like this movie enough that I have pre-ordered the Blu-ray.  Since Amazon does not mention whether or not it will have any extras, I emailed the production company and asked.  They replied that it will have a timelapse of part of the plane being built and a short documentary.

This movie shows among the most realistic "personalities" I have seen in a war movie...people are actually people and not trying for "academy awards" with ridiculous personalities and other bizarre disorders.  This movie shows the importance of becoming part of a crew and being trusted.  It shows the requirement to rise to leadership from "Day #1." They tried to wash out a lot of stuff to cover up flaws or maybe just to save time or both, but it was distracting. I guess the more modern movies have to appeal to modern audiences, though, or today's audiences would not be able to identify with the characters.  The occasional graphic scenes of the bloodiness and mutilation were not in the older movies, and there is one in the cockpit that is quite startling and left me recalling it all the next day. The plot was OK, but not exceptional, as the same thing probably happened hundreds of times. For me, 12 O'Clock High and Command Decision were exceptional 5 star movies and I have watched each of them more than 5 times apiece.

After hearing the stories from my Dad and My father-in-law, a B - 17 or 24 navigator during WWII, I can now see more clearly what they were talking about. They are both gone now, but I reveled in the camaraderie, passion and heroism of the fighting men of all the services. I believe there are few movies of this type that are epic and stay close to the way it was without over glamorizing a horrible time in the history of the world. This movie made me cry, swell with pride for my fellow Americans, and hurt deeply for the thousand who died. I've bought a few movies for my daughter to watch and I intend to buy this one for her. I think anyone who has never served needs to see what those who did sacrificed. I don't intend anything more than to inform those who have never experienced the fear, dread or absolute panic of war and the courage it takes to overcome these feeling and do what need to be done. This movie shows that exactly.

There are a couple of moments in this otherwise engaging film that the CGI completely (and I mean *THOROUGHLY*) screws the pooch through incredible distortions of scale. And tactics: it would have helped considerably if the producers had hired a military consultant familiar with the "box formation" that made the B-17s so deadly to approach, with each tight group of Fortresses protecting not only its own group but nearby groups as well. This movie fills the sky with hundreds of random airplanes, and I do mean "RANDOM"!! The near-misses and other hair-raising encounters depicted herein are ... well, laughable. But I digress from my main point: SCALE! There are shots where it's painfully obvious that the B-17s are CGI, and the talent is acting on a green stage, and perhaps several layers of this is going on in the background while people are green-screened chatting in the foreground. The background plate is either a live-action or still photo of a B-17 on the ground, and this thing is GINORMOUS!! It's the size of a 747!! The American propaganda image of the B-17 as a giant was true ... IN ITS DAY! It was born of the era in which Amelia Earhart disappeared near Nikumaroro, but it is almost *NEVER* depicted as it truly was: a cramped, freezing, noisy and just-up-to-the-job technological wonder on the cutting edge of reliability. There's a shot of the crew bailing out of a hatch on the starboard side of the airplane, aft of the waist gunner's position. The hatch would fit a 777, the guys standing in the door are standing upright and have headroom. Truth be told, there was no such hatch in a B-17, and the fuselage at the waist gunners' position was scarcely 5' in diameter (not radius ... DIAMETER!) The best description I ever heard from a B-17 vet, a waist gunner, of his place in the airplane in combat, was "...two guys with jackhammers in a phone booth." SO: the story is engaging and well-acted, it's wrapped in cheaply researched and poorly done computer graphics with perhaps a few expensive and constantly-repurposed air-to-air shots with a flying B-17 (Commemorative Air Force?) (matted into a single shot 30 times?) but for all its shortcomings, it's a very enjoyable film and if you like flyin' films ("Flight of the Phoenix" Stewart/Attenborough, "Flight From Ashiya", "Fate Is The Hunter", "Twelve O'clock High", et al) then please let me recommend this film. Oh, one other minor point for the practical and makeup effects guys: blood blackens as it coagulates and dries, even in sub-zero high-altitude conditions. The bright cherry candy red staying bright cherry candy red was another distraction. Didn't *LOVE IT* but have to admit, I liked it a lot. Even watched it again all the way through when I started it and realized, "Oh, yeah, I saw this one ..."

Well, it's a plain fact that the German 20 mm cannon was hell on door gunners and crewmembers. It was pure butchery, plain and simple. The air war boiled down to a race to the bottom of German replacements and fuel. As the war burned on, German boys weren't any match for American fighter pilots. This movie really makes it clear that luck was a major factor in survival. Never knew about the ethanol in the fuel. American bomber crews were actually under a death sentence. The odds of completing 25 successful missions was so close to impossible as to be sickening.

What most people don't realize is just how young those bomber crews really were. 18-20 years old, and the Officers were a couple of years older. The bombers were literally sitting ducks. It was very difficult to hit a fighter flying almost 400 mph. No real armor to speak off, and flak and 20 mm cannon shells went thru whatever was hit. Most shot up crewmen bled to death in 30 below zero. So, Fortress is a good movie, just understand what you're seeing.

Blame that one on the writers and the director.  Seriously guys, if you're going to make a period film, study the period.  And, while you're out shopping for a dialect coach, movement coach, and voice coach, see if you can find a smoking coach.  Really; non-smokers who are trying to look like they habitually smoke come off looking clumsy at best; and 70 years ago, nearly all men (and very few women) smoked.

I was particularly impressed by the CGI of the B-17 bombers.  More than 19,000 of those aircraft were built, but today the only way to find a real one that can fly is to build it from scratch.  One silly tip that I didn't even think about until I started writing a review:  Aluminum airplane wings flex in flight; just a little, but it would have been enough to notice in the external close-up flying scenes.

This was a pretty decent movie about a crew of a B-17 bomber in WWII. I liked it because it showed the seldom-seen Italian front from the air war side. Most of these movies depict the Western front while this one was about Africa and Italy. I found the situations and actor's behavior to be realistic and representative of the times. I do have sympathy with those people who took issue with all of the F-bombs, but for good or bad, it was a realistic representation of how these crews talked. I for one am not going to apply our 21st century PC glasses to condemn the generation who saved all of us from ourselves. One scene I particularly enjoyed occurred when the new co-pilot was doing everything he could to keep one of the enlisted men from facing a court martial. His concocted story where he received the blame got the man off the hook while amusing the base CO at the same time. I could see this happening at a time when the commander needed every available man to send on missions. The last thing he needed was a crewmember in the brig just to satisfy a junior officer's vanity. All in all, this was a very enjoyable way to spend an evening.

I was born in the closing weeks of WW II so there was zero chance I could do my part although my parents did theirs.  But all my life I have felt a certain guilt that I was not able to do something to contribute to that epic battle to literally save the world for Democracy.

The men and women who lived through, and fought that noble fight and those that never made it "home" deserve our ever lasting gratitude and eternal respect.

They were, and will always remain, for me and for so any others: "The Greatest Generation"

I try to watch every film, that like FORTRESS, makes us pause and think how I would have withstood the non stop horror, the constant fear, the continuous awareness , 24/7, that maybe today or tomorrow or next week, my luck will run out and I also will just become another statistic, returning home in a Flag Draped coffin.

In the very opening of the film one reads a brief text that the men we are about to "meet" in this film belonged to Divisions where you had to complete a minimum of 25 successful bombing missions before you could be relieved from further future flying missions.  And this statement was followed with the words that only 2 out of every 25 flying groups ever survived long enough to complete their required 25 bombing runs to be relieved from those Divisions.

Those are pretty thin odds.  And how many of those brave flyers did make it home but without arms, legs, faces and/or their eyesight to gaze once more on those they loved and had left behind.

Those who give a film like this less than 4 or 5 Stars,  because the film had a limited budget that did not allow for all the Hollywood glitz and special effects one encounters in a 10 or 20 Million dollar Mega production miss the whole point of the film.

And likely such "film critics" were not there, did not serve, do not have the faintest clue as to what it was like to be there at that time in history.

I grew up around such people who were there, in those planes, who were among those who were part of the waves of soldiers who stormed the beaches of Normandy, literally forced to run into the onslaught of German machine gun fire as soon as they stepped on the beach.

How many of those brave men were simply cut down the moment their boots touched the sand, cut down in the prime of their life.

Some may say that the negative critics here are simply rating the film according to their personal expectations of what a film must contain and achieve to be considered a 5 Star film.

Well, good for them for being so demanding and so "discriminating".  And how admirable that they have the boundless "courage" to turn off and stop watching a film that does not cut it for them and/or make the grade according to their lofty expectations.

I wonder just how courageous such demanding critics would have been if asked to board one of the bombers we see in this film and fly every single day into the Jaws of Hell.

For me personally I want a movie to envelope me with its story and its message and make me think and feel and be moved and remember all the characters and their faces and their dreams and yes- their ultimate Sacrifices freely made for the sake of Humanity.

I do not need to watch a 40 million dollar "Star Wars" type spectacle to feel I did not waste my money or two precious hours of my life, which I can never replace.

When I view a film I hope it will make me think about life, about what others have done and sacrificed, before me, to make this a better world for those who follow.

And FORTRESS achieves that in Spades.

And for the record, those who gave this powerful movie just 1 or 2 Stars- that's probably 1 or 2 Stars more than such people would have ever received in the Military- if such people had ever served in the Military in the first place to protect the Nation in which they lived.

Bravo and bravo encore to the Director, the Writer, the Producers, the Actors and all who took part in bringing FORTRESS to fruition.  It is a Film which will endure for generations to come.

The flight scenes are obviously 3D renders, and not top notch ones either, even for 2012. They look slightly- slightly- better than my IL2 Sturmovik PC game jacked up to full.

Now, I'm a B-17 junkie and have been my whole remembered life. The stories, the pictures, the footage, the museums, I've seen it all. If you're a B-17 junkie too, this movie is a "must see" but don't expect a "Memphis Belle." Nothing can compare to actual B-17's flying. That being said, the story was different than the "typical" heavy bomber movie based in England and making runs over Germany. The base in Libya and flights to Italy/Sicily are a nice change.

The character story is tenuous at best though. A crew of all Irish Americans, who make every effort to make Irish jokes and stay drunk all the time? It was rare to have a crew all from a certain area, although I suppose it could happen. The crew are always hung over and again, while I'm certain this happened on occasion, a whole crew of alcoholics wouldn't have survived many missions.

**SPOILERS**

The new co-pilot arrives and is understandably concerned about the behavior of his new crew. His good judge in character is short lived as he folds and begins to adapt to the new crew, instead of requesting a transfer or filing a report.

However, the flight segments are pretty good once you get past the graphics. The action portion of the story is filled with the horrors of aerial combat, although the apparent "green" status of the crew shows itself here, too.

In closing, there are movies made about "crack" bomber crews, but there are very few that show the horrors that accompany being "ate up" and this movie seems to cover that, albeit unintentionally. When you read about crews that just didn't cut it, you wind up with a story like this.

Fortress is one of those really good movies that slip through the cracks somehow.  Based on true accounts during World War II, Fortress follows the crew of Lucky Lass, a B-17 Flying Fortress.

Having been a crewmember in aircraft a good deal of my career, the producers, director and actors definitely got the camaraderie part right.  You're either a crew or you aren't.  In times of war (or other high stress non-wartimes), that closeness is what gets a crew through even the worst of times.

What I really did appreciate was that the producers took the time to let people know at the end of the movie, they could not possibly duplicate the aircraft faithfully and a few other things.  In fact, what they put out was pretty darn funny.

Fortress is a good movie.  There's laughter, tears, scary moments and goofiness.  There's even the typical "Zero" (officer) who thinks his job is to make sure nobody steps out of line.  There's a time and a place for that kind of overseeing.  The Skipper seemed to know it was BS.

Fortress is worth watching.  If you like historical movies - it's worthwhile.  If you like movies of friendship - it's worthwhile.  If you like airplane movies and I don't mean the movie Airplane, although that's another story - it's worthwhile.

I bought Fortress on the recommendation of a friend, and from the very first moment I was hooked!  Starring Bug Hall, Donnie Jeffcoat, Sean McGowan, and Manu Intiraymi, this movie tells the story of a B-17 bomber crew who, after losing their original commander in a raid over Sicily, find themselves having to deal with breaking in the replacement, a young pilot who has no clue how to fit in, and who seems to do everything wrong at first, alienating the men he's supposed to be commanding.

The thing I loved most about this film is the acting.  The stars bring a freshness and vitality to the story that seems to be lacking in most big-budget Hollywood war epics, and they are the best and brightest of today's crop of young actors.  I definitely hope to see more from this bunch!

The story was very good as well.  Some of the pranks that the Lucky Lass's crew pulled on their new commander (and each other) brought to mind some of the stories I used to hear from my father about his service in the Navy Seabees, and I spent a good amount of time watching Fortress and being just plain awestruck at how real the Lucky Lass and her crew felt to me because of the things they would do.

All in all, Fortress was a wonderful movie, and I would definitely recommend it to anyone without hesitation.

We usually think of the B-17 as the 8th Air Force strategic bomber that struck Germany from Britain in 1943-45 as depicted in Twelve O'Clock High and similar movies. This film shows us a different and previously neglected look at the campaign in north Africa in 1943 against Axis targets in the Mediteranean theater, It is also different in showing ethnic tensions between members of a combat crew instead of the usual idealised image of a melting pot of every American economic, regional, religious and immigrant stock. The B-17s themselves are computer generated but the generation is for once done so well that it is sometimes possible to forget that it is being done. It is not the same as actually watching historic combat footage or a survivor B-17 that can actually fly. But it was a pleasant surprise to view this movie. Recommended.

I too saw this movie at the store so I picked it since I collect WWII movies.  I'll try to break this review down into several things.

The actors did an okay job.  Remember that most air crews, especially replacements, in WWII were very young.  If you were 25 years old you were considered an "old man".  The crews in this movie are a lot younger than say those in Memphis Belle which gives it some credability.  Remember our grandfathers were just young kids barely out of high school who fought WWII.  There were not 40 year old Hollywood A list actors like in Saving Private Ryan.

A few people have ccomplained about the drinking in the film.  Again, having served myself in the Army in the GWOT, I think the drinking is right on.  Everyone deals with things in their own way.  For many they turn to alcohol.

As far as no threat or fear, obviously the other reviewer has not done any history research about the air crews in WWII.  The threat of death that ground troops faced 24/7 did not impact the air crews.  While they did go into danger during bombing runs and suffer heavy casualties, they were able to retreat to safety between the missions.  You don't sit there worrying about getting killed, you block it out.  In other words you ddon't want to think about it so you do anything not to.  Ground troops didn't have this option.

As far as CGI and things looking fake, what "looks" real?  Even Redtails that had a budget in the millions used CGI.  Even Memphis Belle used toy models for many of the damage sequences.  If you pay attention to the story line you can easily overlook the few CGI errors.  In fact most of it looked pretty good considering the low budget.

The argument that one reviewer tried to make that the sounds were wrong is pointless.  If ANY movie sounded like it realy did up there you would not b able to hear anything except engine noise.  I have been around many warbirds and the sound is deafening.  Remember the 1940s was a time before OSHA required earplugs.  This is no different than any military movie where the soldiers are firing guns.  My ears would ring firing an M16 let alone what air crews heard firing ten 50 cals per B17.

Overall this is a good movie with a nice story line.  The lack of super big name A list actors makes it more believable.  If you love B17s you will enjoy this movie.  The fact that story takes place focusing on the Italy raids is a nice change from all the focus of raids on France and Germany.  And a B17 base somewhere other than England is a nice change also.  I highly recommend this movie.

FORTRESS does for bomber crews what Saving Private Ryan and a score of others did for the infantry and what Das Boot - The Director's Cut and U-571 did for submariners. Aerial combat is perhaps the most easily glamorized aspect of warfare, and this film effectively shows just how "glamorous" it was to be a crew member on a WWII bomber. Many of the scenes shot inside the B-17 hark back to the days of Midway; i.e., the plane is obviously not actually flying. Still, the outside shots of the bombing missions and duels with German fighters are quite arresting in places, usually without the animation being too obvious. We're convincingly shown a great many technical details of WWII bomber flying here, and the way FORTRESS combines the gritty realism of today's war films with some of the endearingly corny plot elements of older films works quite well. The biggest weakness is that the central characters are rather flat and under-developed. Admittedly, it would be hard to reveal the personalities of all 10 crew members in any detail without becoming ponderous, but something more in the way of human interest would help here.

But, I will say, it definitely came together at the end.  Also, the quality of the visual effects wasn't always consistent.  But, all and all (and for an indie film), I was surprised at the number of good quality CG shots.  They weren't up to snuff with movies like "Red Tails" or "John Carter," but these guys were clearly working with a different budget, entirely.

In general, I can definitely say this is not your typical low budget film. The filmmakers were obviously very ambitious and did a lot with what was probably a shoe string budget, and they were able to do it without substantially detracting from the story.  I thoroughly enjoyed it and will watch it again.
